term.name: abdomen
term.description: Rear or bottom end of an animal's main body.

term.name: acetic acid
term.description: The old name for ethanoic acid. It is the acid in vinegar.

term.name: acid
term.description: A substance that turns litmus red. It has a pH of less than 7.

term.name: acid rain
term.description: Rain containing sulphuric and nitric acid.

term.name: acne
term.description: Spots on the skin.

term.name: adaptations
term.description: The features that plants and animals have to help them live in a particular place.

term.name: adapted
term.description: When something has certain features to help it do a particular job. When the features of a cell help it do its job, the cell is said to be 'adapted' to its job.

term.name: adolescence
term.description: Time when both physical and emotional changes occur in humans.

term.name: afterbirth
term.description: When the placenta is pushed out through the vagina.

term.name: air resistance
term.description: A force that tries to slow things down that are moving through air. It is a type of friction.

term.name: alkali
term.description: Substance that turns litmus blue. Has a pH of more than 7.

term.name: alternative energy resources
term.description: Another name for renewable energy resources.

term.name: ammeter
term.description: Measures how much electricity is flowing around a circuit.

term.name: amnion
term.description: Bag containing amniotic fluid.

term.name: amniotic fluid
term.description: Liquid surrounding the growing embryo and protecting it.

term.name: amp (A)
term.description: The unit for current.

term.name: amphibian
term.description: Vertebrate with moist skin, e.g. a frog.

term.name: antacid
term.description: A medicine containing an alkali used to cancel out some of the acid in the stomach to treat heartburn.

term.name: ante-natal class
term.description: A pregnant woman and the father of the baby attend this to find out more about what happens during pregnancy and childbirth.

term.name: antenna
term.description: Something sticking out of an animal's head which is used to sense things. The plural is antennae.

term.name: anther
term.description: Part of the stamen. It produces pollen grains.

term.name: antibodies
term.description: Substances produced by white blood cells that help to fight microbes which might cause diseases.

term.name: arachnid
term.description: Type of arthropod with four pairs of legs, e.g. a spider.

term.name: arthropod
term.description: Invertebrate with jointed legs, e.g. a fly or spider.

term.name: ascorbic acid
term.description: Chemical name for vitamin C.

term.name: asteroid
term.description: A small lump of rock orbiting around the Sun

term.name: atom
term.description: The smallest part of an element.

term.name: axis
term.description: Imaginary vertical line that goes from one pole of the Earth to the other. The Earth spins around its axis.

term.name: balanced forces
term.description: When two forces are the same strength, but working in opposite directions.

term.name: biomass
term.description: Any fuel that comes from plants, animals, or their wastes (e.g. wood, methane from rotting plants, etc.).

term.name: bird
term.description: Vertebrate with feathers, e.g. an eagle.

term.name: bonds
term.description: Forces holding particles together.

term.name: brain
term.description: Organ that controls what the body does.

term.name: braking distance
term.description: The distance a car travels while the brakes are trying to stop it.

term.name: breathing system
term.description: Takes in oxygen and gets rid of carbon dioxide from our bodies.

term.name: brine
term.description: A solution of common salt and water.

term.name: buoyancy aids
term.description: A jacket filled with foam that helps you to float in water.

term.name: burette
term.description: A tube with a tap at the bottom and a measuring scale on its side. Used to add a measured quantity of a liquid to another one.

term.name: cable grip
term.description: Part of a plug that holds the cable, and stops the wires being pulled out of the pins.

term.name: carbon dioxide
term.description: A gas which will put out a lighted splint and turn limewater milky.

term.name: carnivore
term.description: An animal that only eats other animals.

term.name: carpel
term.description: Female reproductive organ found in flowers. It is made of a stigma, style and ovary.

term.name: cell (biology)
term.description: The basic unit which living things are made of.

term.name: cell (physics)
term.description: A source of electricity with a low 'energy'. Cells push electrons round a circuit.

term.name: cell division
term.description: When a cell splits in two. Cells are made using cell division.

term.name: cell surface membrane
term.description: Controls what goes into and out of a cell.

term.name: cell wall
term.description: Tough wall around plant cells. Helps to support the cell.

term.name: cellulose
term.description: Tough material used to make plant cell walls.

term.name: centipede
term.description: Type of arthropod with long thin body divided into sections. One pair of legs on each body section.

term.name: cervix
term.description: Ring of muscle at the bottom of the uterus in females.

term.name: chemical energy
term.description: The kind of energy stored in chemicals. Food, fuels and cells (batteries) all contain chemical energy.

term.name: chemical reaction
term.description: When new substances are formed.

term.name: chlorophyll
term.description: Green substance found inside chloroplasts.

term.name: chloroplast
term.description: Green disc containing chlorophyll. Found in plant cells. Where the plant makes food using photosynthesis.

term.name: choice chamber
term.description: Equipment that allows scientists to test how environmental factors affect organisms.

term.name: chromatogram
term.description: The dried piece of paper produced by chromatography.

term.name: chromatography
term.description: Separating dissolved solids from one another. The solids are usually coloured.

term.name: cilia
term.description: Small hairs on the surface of some cells.

term.name: ciliated
term.description: Having cilia.

term.name: ciliated epithelial cell
term.description: Cell with cilia found in the lungs.

term.name: circuit
term.description: A complete loop that electricity flows around.

term.name: circulatory system
term.description: Carries oxygen and food around the body.

term.name: circumcision
term.description: Removal of the foreskin.

term.name: citric acid
term.description: The acid in citrus fruits.

term.name: classification
term.description: Sorting things into groups.

term.name: coal
term.description: A fossil fuel made from the remains of plants.

term.name: combination reaction
term.description: When chemicals join to form new substances.

term.name: combustion
term.description: The scientific word for burning.

term.name: common salt
term.description: A chemical we use to make things taste 'salty'.

term.name: community
term.description: All the plants and animals that live in a habitat.

term.name: compete
term.description: All organisms need some of the same things and so each organism has to try to get these things before another organism does. For example, plants compete with one another for light.

term.name: concentrate
term.description: We concentrate a solution by adding more of the solute to it.

term.name: contraction
term.description: When something is getting smaller.

term.name: component
term.description: Something in a circuit, like a bulb, switch or motor.

term.name: condensing
term.description: A gas turning into a liquid.

term.name: conductor
term.description: A material that lets electricity flow through it.

term.name: constellation
term.description: A pattern of stars.

term.name: consumer
term.description: An organism that has to eat other organisms to stay alive. Animals are consumers.

term.name: contact force
term.description: A force that needs to touch an object before it can affect it (e.g. friction).

term.name: continuous
term.description: Variation where there is a range of values which change gradually, such as the height of people.

term.name: contraction
term.description: When something is getting smaller.

term.name: contractions
term.description: The uterus starts to push out the baby during labour.

term.name: convection current
term.description: A flow of liquid or gas caused by part of it being heated or cooled more than the rest.

term.name: cord
term.description: Carries food, oxygen and waste between the placenta and the growing fetus.

term.name: correlation
term.description: Same as a relationship.

term.name: corrosion
term.description: When stone or metal reacts with chemicals in air or water and is worn away or changed into a different substance.

term.name: corrosive
term.description: Substances that attack metals, stonework and skin are called corrosive.

term.name: coverslip
term.description: Thin piece of glass used to hold a specimen in place on a slide.

term.name: cross-pollination
term.description: Transfer of pollen from an anther to a stigma of a different plant.

term.name: crude oil
term.description: A mixture of different liquids found underground. It includes the liquids we use as petrol and engine oil.

term.name: crustacean
term.description: Type of arthropod with a chalky shell and 5-7 pairs of legs, e.g. a lobster.

term.name: cytoplasm
term.description: Jelly inside a cell where the cell's activities happen.

term.name: daily changes
term.description: Changes in the physical environmental factors which happen during a day (e.g. it gets dark at night).

term.name: data
term.description: Results of an experiment.

term.name: daughter cell
term.description: The two new cells made by cell division are called daughter cells.

term.name: day
term.description: 24 hours, the time it takes the Earth to spin once on its axis.

term.name: deciduous
term.description: Tree that drops its leaves in winter (e.g. oak tree).

term.name: decomposer
term.description: Something that eats dead plants.

term.name: decomposition reaction
term.description: A reaction where a chemical breaks up to form other compounds. A decomposition reaction does not require oxygen from the air.

term.name: dense
term.description: Something which is heavy for its volume.

term.name: density
term.description: The amount of mass that 1cm3 of a substance has. Measured in g/cm3.

term.name: desalination
term.description: Removing salt from sea water.

term.name: diffusion
term.description: When particles mix with each other without anything moving them.

term.name: digestive system
term.description: Breaks down our food.

term.name: dilute
term.description: We dilute a solution by adding more of the solvent to it.

term.name: discontinuous
term.description: Variation where there are only a few different options, such as people who can roll their tongues and those who cannot.

term.name: displacement
term.description: The volume of water pushed out of the way by an object.

term.name: dissolving
term.description: When a solid splits up and mixes with a liquid to make a solution.

term.name: distance/time graph
term.description: A graph that shows how far and how fast something travels during a journey.

term.name: distillation
term.description: The process of separating a liquid from a solution by evaporating the liquid and then condensing it.

term.name: distribution
term.description: The places where an organism can be found in a habitat.

term.name: drag
term.description: Air resistance and water resistance are both sometimes called drag.

term.name: Earth
term.description: The planet we live on.

term.name: earth wire
term.description: The green and yellow wire in a cable or plug.

term.name: echinoderm
term.description: Invertebrate with a body in five parts, e.g. a starfish.

term.name: egg cell
term.description: The female sex cell.

term.name: ejaculation
term.description: Semen is pumped out of a man's penis into the top of the vagina during sexual intercourse.

term.name: elastic
term.description: Any substance that will return to its original shape and size after it has been stretched or squashed.

term.name: electric current
term.description: The flow of electricity around a circuit.

term.name: electric shock
term.description: When electricity flows through the body.

term.name: electrical energy
term.description: The kind of energy carried by electricity.

term.name: electron
term.description: Tiny particle that flows around a circuit.

term.name: embryo (human)
term.description: Tiny new human life which grows by cell division from a fertilised egg cell.

term.name: embryo (plant)
term.description: Tiny plant, found inside a seed, with a very small shoot and a very small root.

term.name: environment
term.description: The conditions around a certain organism caused by physical environmental factors.

term.name: environmental factors
term.description: Things in an environment that can change something about an organism.

term.name: environmental variation
term.description: Differences between organisms caused by environmental factors.

term.name: erection
term.description: When the penis becomes stiff.

term.name: ethanoic acid
term.description: The acid in vinegar.

term.name: evaporation
term.description: A liquid turning into a gas.

term.name: evergreen
term.description: Tree that keeps its leaves in winter (e.g. pine tree).

term.name: exoskeleton
term.description: Thick outer covering found on arthropods.

term.name: expansion
term.description: When something gets bigger.

term.name: explosives
term.description: Chemicals which are designed to explode (to produce large amounts of gas very quickly).

term.name: external fertilisation
term.description: When fertilisation happens outside the bodies of the parents.

term.name: eyepiece lens
term.description: Part of the microscope you look down.

term.name: fertilisation
term.description: Fusing of a male sex cell with a female sex cell.

term.name: fertilised egg cell
term.description: What is produced when a male sex cell fuses with an egg cell.

term.name: fetus
term.description: After an embryo has grown all its organs it is called a fetus. This is usually at about 10 weeks.

term.name: filament (biology)
term.description: Part of the stamen. It supports the anther.

term.name: filament (physics)
term.description: Thin piece of wire inside a light bulb that glows when electricity is flowing through it.

term.name: filtering
term.description: Separating things that have not dissolved from a liquid. The liquid is passed through a filter to do this.

term.name: fire triangle
term.description: A triangle that shows the three things needed for a fire to keep burning: heat, fuel and oxygen.

term.name: fish
term.description: Vertebrate with wet scales, fins and gills, e.g. a salmon.

term.name: flow
term.description: Move.

term.name: flower
term.description: Organ system containing reproductive organs - carpel (female), stamen (male).

term.name: focusing wheel
term.description: Wheel on a microscope that moves parts of the microscope to get the image into focus.

term.name: food chain
term.description: A way of showing what eats what in a habitat.

term.name: food web
term.description: Many food chains linked together.

term.name: force
term.description: A push or a pull.

term.name: force meter
term.description: Piece of equipment containing a spring, used to measure forces.

term.name: foreskin
term.description: A covering of skin protecting the head of the penis.

term.name: fossil
term.description: A dead organism that has been trapped in mud and whose body has not completely rotted away.

term.name: fossil fuels
term.description: Coal, oil and natural gas - all fuels that were formed from the remains of dead plants and animals.

term.name: fractional distillation
term.description: A way of separating liquids with different boiling points.

term.name: fractionating tower
term.description: Large tower used to separate the different liquids in crude oil.

term.name: friction
term.description: A force that tries to slow things down when two things rub against each other.

term.name: fruit
term.description: Something used to carry seeds. Can be fleshy or dry.

term.name: fuel
term.description: Anything that stores energy that can be converted into heat energy - includes fossil fuels and nuclear fuel.

term.name: full moon
term.description: The phase of the Moon when it looks like a bright, full circle.

term.name: function
term.description: Something's job.

term.name: fuse (biology)
term.description: When two sex cells join together to form a fertilised egg cell they are said to fuse.

term.name: fuse (physics)
term.description: A piece of wire that melts if too much electricity flows through it.

term.name: galaxy
term.description: Millions of stars grouped together.

term.name: gas
term.description: Something that does not have a fixed shape or volume, and is easy to squash.

term.name: generate
term.description: Make electricity by turning a magnet inside coils of wire.

term.name: generator
term.description: Large coil of wire with a magnet inside. When the magnet is turned, electricity is produced in the coil of wire.

term.name: geothermal power
term.description: Making electricity using heat from hot rocks underground.

term.name: gestation period
term.description: The length of time from fertilisation to birth.

term.name: glands
term.description: The glands in the male reproductive system add a special liquid to the sperm cells to make semen. There are other sorts of glands in the body.

term.name: gram
term.description: A unit for measuring mass (g).

term.name: gravity
term.description: The force of attraction between any two objects. The Earth is very big and so has strong gravity that pulls everything down towards it.

term.name: habitat
term.description: The place an organism lives in (e.g. woodland).

term.name: harmful
term.description: Another word for irritant.

term.name: head
term.description: Front or top end of an animal's body.

term.name: heart
term.description: Organ that pumps blood.

term.name: heat energy
term.description: The hotter something is, the more heat energy it has.

term.name: heat exchanger
term.description: Piece of equipment used in desalination to take heat away from steam and turn it into water.

term.name: hemispheres
term.description: The two halves of a sphere - the shape you would get if you cut a solid ball in half.

term.name: herbivore
term.description: An animal that only eats plants.

term.name: hibernation
term.description: When animals hide during the winter and go to sleep.

term.name: host
term.description: An animal that has a parasite living on it or inside it.

term.name: hydrocarbon
term.description: A chemical compound containing only hydrogen and carbon.

term.name: hydrochloric acid
term.description: A common acid that is also found in your stomach.

term.name: hydroelectric power
term.description: Making electricity by letting falling water (usually from a reservoir) turn turbines and generators.

term.name: image
term.description: What you see down a microscope.

term.name: implantation
term.description: When an embryo sinks into the soft lining of the uterus.

term.name: impulse
term.description: Electrical signal carried by a nerve cell.

term.name: in focus
term.description: When an image is clear and sharp.

term.name: in parallel
term.description: When a voltmeter is connected across a bulb or other component.

term.name: indicator
term.description: A dye that will change colour in acids and alkalis.

term.name: inflate
term.description: To blow air into something.

term.name: inherit
term.description: Something passed on from our parents.

term.name: inherited variation
term.description: Differences between organisms passed to organisms by their parents in reproduction.

term.name: inner planets
term.description: Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars. The inner planets are all rocky planets.

term.name: insect
term.description: Type of arthropod with three pairs of legs, e.g. a fly.

term.name: insoluble
term.description: A solid that will not dissolve.

term.name: insulator
term.description: A material that does not let electricity flow through it.

term.name: internal fertilisation
term.description: When fertilisation happens inside the bodies of the parents.

term.name: intestine
term.description: The small intestine is an organ used to digest and absorb food. The large intestine is an organ which removes water from unwanted food.

term.name: invertebrate
term.description: Animal with no backbone.

term.name: irreversible action
term.description: A reaction in which what you end up with cannot be turned back into what you started with.

term.name: irreversible change
term.description: Permanent change.

term.name: irritant
term.description: Something that irritates the skin and eyes.

term.name: IVF
term.description: In Vitrio Fertilisation ('in glass') a method of fertilising an egg outside the woman's body by injecting a sperm cell into it.

term.name: joule (J)
term.description: The unit for measuring energy.

term.name: kidneys
term.description: Organs used to clean the blood and make urine.

term.name: kilogram
term.description: A unit for measuring mass (kg). There are 1000 g in 1 kg.

term.name: kilojoule (kJ)
term.description: There are 1000 joules in 1 kilojoule.

term.name: kilometres per hour (km/h)
term.description: Units for speed when the distance is measured in kilometres and the time is measured in hours.

term.name: kinetic energy
term.description: The kind of energy in moving things.

term.name: kingdom
term.description: Largest groups that living things are sorted into. The two biggest are the plant and animal kingdoms.

term.name: labour
term.description: Time when the baby is about to be born.

term.name: law of conservation of energy
term.description: The idea that energy can never be created or destroyed, only changed from one form into another.

term.name: leaf
term.description: Plant organ used to make food using photosynthesis.

term.name: leap year
term.description: A year with 366 days in it. We have a leap year every 4 years.

term.name: light energy
term.description: The kind of energy given out by light bulbs, candles, etc.

term.name: light source
term.description: Something that gives out light.

term.name: light year
term.description: The distance that light travels in one year.

term.name: limewater
term.description: A chemical that goes cloudy when carbon dioxide is bubbled through it.

term.name: liquid
term.description: Something with a fixed volume but no fixed shape.

term.name: litmus
term.description: A simple kind of indicator. It turns red in acids and blue in alkalis.

term.name: live wire
term.description: The brown wire in a cable or plug.

term.name: liver
term.description: Organ used to make and destroy substances in our bodies.

term.name: lubricant
term.description: A substance (normally a liquid) used to reduce friction.

term.name: lubrication
term.description: Adding a lubricant to something.

term.name: luminous
term.description: Gives out light.

term.name: lunar eclipse
term.description: When the Moon moves into the shadow of the Earth.

term.name: lunar month
term.description: 28 days - the time it takes the Moon to orbit around the Earth once.

term.name: lungs
term.description: Organs used to take oxygen out of the air and put waste carbon dioxide into the air.

term.name: magnetism
term.description: A force that attracts objects made out of iron.

term.name: magnification
term.description: How much bigger a microscope makes something appear.

term.name: mains (electricity)
term.description: Alternating current at 230 V provided to houses, shops etc.

term.name: mammal
term.description: Vertebrate with hair, which also produces milk, e.g. a human.

term.name: mammary glands
term.description: Glands contained in the breasts of women which produce milk after childbirth.

term.name: mass
term.description: The amount of matter that something is made of. Measured in grams (g) and kilograms (kg). Your mass does not change if you go into space or to another planet.

term.name: mature
term.description: Another word for develop.

term.name: menopause
term.description: When the ovaries in women stop releasing eggs.

term.name: menstrual cycle
term.description: Series of events lasting about a month, happening in the female reproductive system. The cycle causes ovulation and the lining of the uterus is replaced.

term.name: menstruation
term.description: When the lining of the uterus and a little blood pass out of the vagina as part of the menstrual cycle.

term.name: metal
term.description: A type of substance that is shiny, conducts heat and electricity well, and has high melting and boiling points.

term.name: metres per second (m/s)
term.description: Units for speed when the distance is measured in metres and the time is measured in seconds.

term.name: microhabitat
term.description: Small areas of a habitat with certain conditions (e.g. under a log in a woodland habitat).

term.name: microscope
term.description: Used to magnify small things.

term.name: migration
term.description: When animals move to different areas of the world depending on the season.

term.name: miles per hour (mph)
term.description: Units for speed when the distance is measured in miles and the time is measured in hours.

term.name: Milky Way
term.description: The galaxy that our Solar System is in.

term.name: millipede
term.description: Arthropod with long, thin body divided into sections. Two pairs of legs on each body section.

term.name: mixture
term.description: A lot of different things jumbled up together.

term.name: model
term.description: A scientific way of thinking about how things happen.

term.name: mollusc
term.description: Invertebrate that crawls on a fleshy pad, e.g. a snail.

term.name: Moon
term.description: A moon is a large lump of rock orbiting around a planet. The Moon is the moon that orbits the Earth.

term.name: muscle cell
term.description: Cell that can change its length and so help us to move.

term.name: muscle tissue
term.description: A group of the same cells that change length and so help us to move.

term.name: natural gas
term.description: Fossil fuel formed from the remains of dead plants and animals that lived in the sea.

term.name: navel
term.description: Scar left by the cord. Often called the 'belly-button'.

term.name: nectar
term.description: Sugary liquid produced in flowers which some insects (and other animals) like to eat.

term.name: nerve
term.description: Carries messages around the body.

term.name: nerve cell
term.description: Cell that carries messages around the body.

term.name: nervous system
term.description: Carries messages around the body.

term.name: neurone
term.description: Another name for a nerve cell.

term.name: neutral
term.description: Substance that is not an acid or an alkali. Has a pH of 7.

term.name: neutral wire
term.description: The blue wire in a cable or plug.

term.name: neutralisation
term.description: When something is neutralised.

term.name: neutralise
term.description: When an acid is added to a base (or alkali) a neutral substance is produced.

term.name: new moon
term.description: The phase of the Moon when we cannot see the lit-up side.

term.name: newton (N)
term.description: The unit of force.

term.name: newton meter
term.description: Another name for a force meter.

term.name: nitric acid
term.description: A common acid.

term.name: nocturnal
term.description: Animals that are active at night.

term.name: non-contact force
term.description: A force that can affect something from a distance (e.g. gravity).

term.name: non-renewable energy resource
term.description: Any energy resource that will run out and we cannot renew our supplies of it (e.g. oil).

term.name: normal distribution
term.description: The bell shape of a graph that shows continuous variation of a particular feature such as height.

term.name: northern hemisphere
term.description: The half of the Earth with the North Pole in it. The UK is in the northern hemisphere.

term.name: nuclear energy
term.description: Energy stored inside the particles that things are made out of.

term.name: nuclear power
term.description: Making electricity by using the nuclear energy stored inside uranium.

term.name: nucleus
term.description: Controls what a cell does.

term.name: objective lens
term.description: Part of the microscope that is closest to what you are looking at.

term.name: observation
term.description: What you see happening in an experiment.

term.name: offspring
term.description: Any plant or animal formed by reproduction. Offspring are produced by their parents.

term.name: oil
term.description: Fossil fuel formed from the remains of dead plants and animals that lived in the sea.

term.name: omnivore
term.description: An animal that eats both plants and other animals.

term.name: orbit
term.description: The path that a planet takes around the Sun, or the path that a moon or satellite takes around a planet.

term.name: organ
term.description: A large part of a plant or animal that does a very important job.

term.name: organ system
term.description: Collection of organs working together to do a very important job.

term.name: organism
term.description: A living thing.

term.name: outer planets
term.description: Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune and Pluto. All the outer planets except Pluto are made of gas.

term.name: ovary (humans)
term.description: Female reproductive organ. Produces egg cells.

term.name: ovary (plants)
term.description: Part of the carpel. It contains ovules, each of which contains an egg cell.

term.name: oviduct
term.description: Carries egg cells from the ovaries to the uterus in women. Fertilisation happens here.

term.name: ovulation
term.description: Releasing of an egg cell from an ovary in women.

term.name: ovule
term.description: Contains egg cells. Is found in the ovary.

term.name: oxide
term.description: A compound that includes oxygen.

term.name: palisade cell
term.description: Cell found in leaves which contains many chloroplasts.

term.name: parallel circuit
term.description: A circuit with two or more wires running next to each other.

term.name: parasite
term.description: An animal that lives on or inside another living animal. Most parasites feed on blood.

term.name: parent
term.description: An organism that has had offspring.

term.name: partial eclipse
term.description: A solar eclipse when the Moon only covers part of the Sun.

term.name: particles
term.description: The tiny pieces that everything is made out of.

term.name: permanent change
term.description: A change in which what you ended up with cannot be turned back into what you started with.

term.name: pH scale
term.description: A numbered scale from 1-14 showing the strengths of acids and alkalis. Numbers below 7 are acids. Numbers above 7 are alkalis. pH 7 is neutral.

term.name: phases of the Moon
term.description: The different shapes the Moon seems to have at different times.

term.name: photosynthesis
term.description: Process that plants use to make their own food. It needs light to work. Carbon dioxide and water are used up. Food (a sugar called glucose) and oxygen are produced.

term.name: physical change
term.description: A change where no new substances are formed.

term.name: physical environmental factors
term.description: The non-living conditions in the environment of an organism (e.g. temperature, light).

term.name: placenta
term.description: Attached to the uterus wall, this takes oxygen and food out of the mother's blood and puts waste materials into the mother's blood.

term.name: plant crossing
term.description: Producing new varieties of plants by pollination between different varieties.

term.name: pollen grain
term.description: The male sex cell in plants.

term.name: pollen tube
term.description: Tube that grows from a pollen grain down through the stigma and style and into the ovary.

term.name: pollination
term.description: Transfer of pollen from an anther to a stigma.

term.name: pollinator
term.description: An animal that carried pollen between plants.

term.name: pooter
term.description: A small container connected to two tubes. Used to catch tiny animals.

term.name: power pack
term.description: A source of electricity with a low energy (low voltage).

term.name: predator
term.description: An animal that catches and eats other animals.

term.name: prediction
term.description: What you think will happen in an experiment.

term.name: pregnant
term.description: When a woman has an embryo growing inside her uterus.

term.name: premature baby
term.description: A small baby born early.

term.name: pressure
term.description: The force caused by particles hitting a certain area.

term.name: prey
term.description: An animal that is caught and eaten by another animal.

term.name: producer
term.description: An organism that is able to make its own food. Plants are producers.

term.name: product
term.description: New chemical formed in a chemical reaction.

term.name: property
term.description: A description of how a material behaves and what it is like. Hardness is a property of some solids.

term.name: puberty
term.description: Time when physical changes happen in the body between the ages of about 11 and 15.

term.name: pure
term.description: A substance that does not have anything else in it.

term.name: quadrat
term.description: A square frame, thrown randomly on the ground, which is used to sample plants in an area.

term.name: radiation
term.description: Dangerous particles and energy given off by uranium and other radioactive materials.

term.name: reactants
term.description: Chemicals that join together to form a new substance.

term.name: relationship
term.description: A link between two things shown on a graph.

term.name: renewable energy resource
term.description: An energy resource that will never run out (e.g. solar power).

term.name: reproductive organ
term.description: Organ that produces sex cells.

term.name: reproductive organs
term.description: Organs used in sexual reproduction.

term.name: reproductive system
term.description: All the reproductive organs.

term.name: reptile
term.description: Vertebrate with dry scales, e.g. a snake.

term.name: resistance
term.description: A way of saying how difficult it is for electricity to flow through something.

term.name: resistor
term.description: A component that makes it difficult for electricity to flow - resistors are used to control the size of the current in a circuit.

term.name: reversible change
term.description: A change in which what you end up with can easily be turned back into what you started with.

term.name: root
term.description: Plant organ used to take water out of the soil.

term.name: root hair cell
term.description: Cell found in roots. It has a large surface area to help the cell absorb water quickly.

term.name: root hair tissue
term.description: Found in roots. Takes in water from the soil.

term.name: rust
term.description: Substance formed when iron or steel reacts with oxygen and water.

term.name: salts
term.description: Chemicals from rocks that have dissolved in water.

term.name: sample
term.description: A small part of something. If you sample something you take a small part of it. You use your results from the small part to suggest what the rest of it is like.

term.name: satellite
term.description: Anything that orbits a planet.

term.name: saturated
term.description: A solution that contains as much dissolved solid as it possibly can.

term.name: scavenger
term.description: An animal that eats animals that have died or been killed by other animals.

term.name: scrotum
term.description: Bag of skin containing the testes in males.

term.name: seasonal changes
term.description: Changes in the physical environmental factors of an environment which happen during the course of a year (e.g. it gets colder in winter).

term.name: segment
term.description: Some animals have bodies that are divided into obvious sections called segments.

term.name: self-pollination
term.description: Transfer of pollen from an anther to stigma of the same plant.

term.name: semen
term.description: A mixture of sperm cells and special fluids released by men during sexual intercourse.

term.name: series circuit
term.description: A circuit where there is only one loop of wire.

term.name: sex cell
term.description: A cell used for sexual reproduction.

term.name: sex hormones
term.description: Chemicals released in our bodies that control the menstrual cycle and puberty.

term.name: sexual reproduction
term.description: Producing new organisms by the joining of two sex cells.

term.name: skin
term.description: Organ used for protection and feeling.

term.name: slide
term.description: Glass sheet that a specimen is put on.

term.name: solar cells
term.description: Flat plates that convert light energy into electrical energy.

term.name: solar eclipse
term.description: When the Moon is between the Sun and the Earth, and casts a shadow on part of the Earth.

term.name: solar panels
term.description: Flat plates that use the Sun"s energy to heat water.

term.name: solar power
term.description: Making electricity by using light or heat energy from the Sun.

term.name: solar system
term.description: A star with planets and other objects orbiting it.

term.name: solid
term.description: Something with a fixed shape and volume.

term.name: solubility
term.description: The amount of a solid that will dissolve in 100g of a liquid.

term.name: soluble
term.description: A solid that can dissolve in a liquid. Salt is soluble in water.

term.name: solute
term.description: The solid that has dissolved in a liquid to make a solution.

term.name: solution
term.description: When a solid has dissolved in a liquid.

term.name: solvent
term.description: The liquid that has dissolved a solid to make a solution.

term.name: sound energy
term.description: The kind of energy made by anything that is making a noise.

term.name: space probe
term.description: An unmanned space craft that has cameras and other equipment to find out about other planets.

term.name: species
term.description: A group of organisms that can reproduce with each other to produce offspring that will also be able to reproduce.

term.name: specimen
term.description: What you look at down a microscope.

term.name: speed
term.description: How fast something is moving. Often measured in metres per second (m/s).

term.name: sperm cell
term.description: The male sex cell.

term.name: sperm count
term.description: The number of sperm produced by a man.

term.name: sperm duct
term.description: Tube that carries sperm from the testes to the urethra.

term.name: sphere
term.description: A shape like a ball.

term.name: stage
term.description: Part of the microscope. You put slides on it.

term.name: stain
term.description: Dye used to colour parts of a cell to make them easier to see.

term.name: stamen
term.description: Male reproductive organ found in flowers. It is made of an anther and a filament.

term.name: star
term.description: A huge ball of gas that gives out heat and light energy.

term.name: states of matter
term.description: There are three different forms which a substance can be in; solid, liquid or gas.

term.name: static electricity
term.description: A force which attracts things with extra electrical charges on them.

term.name: stationary
term.description: Not moving.

term.name: steam
term.description: Water as a gas. Also called water vapour.

term.name: stem
term.description: Plant organ used to take water to the leaves and to support the leaves.

term.name: stigma
term.description: Part of the carpel. It is where pollen lands.

term.name: still
term.description: The apparatus used for distillation.

term.name: stomach
term.description: Organ used to store and break up food.

term.name: stopping distance
term.description: The distance a car moves while it is stopping. The stopping distance is equal to the thinking distance and the braking distance added together.

term.name: style
term.description: Part of the carpel connecting the stigma to the ovary.

term.name: sulphuric acid
term.description: A common acid. Used in car batteries.

term.name: Sun
term.description: The star that the Earth orbits around.

term.name: sweepnet
term.description: A net which is swept through long grass to catch tiny animals.

term.name: sweetener
term.description: A substance that makes things taste sweeter. Sugar is a natural sweetener.

term.name: switch
term.description: Turns electricity on or off, by closing or opening a gap in a circuit.

term.name: testes
term.description: Male reproductive organ. Produces sperm cells. Plural = testes.

term.name: test-tube babies
term.description: A baby born after IVF.

term.name: theory
term.description: An idea about why things work the way they do. Scientists use their imaginations to come up with a theory.

term.name: thinking distance
term.description: The distance a car travels while the driver is deciding to press the brake pedal.

term.name: thorax
term.description: Middle part of an animal's main body. In insects the legs are attached to the thorax.

term.name: tidal power
term.description: Making electricity using the moving (kinetic) energy from the tides.

term.name: tissue
term.description: A group of the same cells all doing the same job.

term.name: top predator
term.description: The last animal in a food chain.

term.name: total eclipse
term.description: A solar eclipse when the Moon completely blocks out light from the Sun.

term.name: transferred
term.description: When energy is changed from one form to another.

term.name: transparent
term.description: Another word for see-through.

term.name: tree beating
term.description: Hitting the branches of a tree and collecting small animals that fall out.

term.name: turbine
term.description: The machine in a power station that is pushed round by water or steam and turns the generator.

term.name: umbilical cord
term.description: Carries food, oxygen and waste between the placenta and the growing fetus.

term.name: unbalanced forces
term.description: When two forces working in opposite directions are not the same strength.

term.name: universal indicator
term.description: A mixture of indicators giving a different colour depending on how weak or strong an acid or alkali is.

term.name: Universe
term.description: All the galaxies and the space between them make up the Universe.

term.name: unstable
term.description: A chemical which can explode very easily is referred to as unstable.

term.name: upthrust
term.description: A force that pushes things up.

term.name: uranium
term.description: A fuel used in nuclear power stations.

term.name: urethra
term.description: A tube carrying semen or urine running down the centre of the penis in males. A tube carrying urine in females.

term.name: uterus
term.description: Organ in females in which a baby develops.

term.name: vacuole
term.description: Storage space in plant cells.

term.name: vacuum
term.description: A completely empty space.

term.name: vagina
term.description: Tube in females. The penis is placed here during sexual intercourse.

term.name: variable resistor
term.description: A resistor that can be adjusted to change the amount of resistance it has.

term.name: variation
term.description: The differences between things.

term.name: variety
term.description: A plant or animal that is in some way different from its parents.

term.name: vertebrate
term.description: An animal with a backbone.

term.name: vibrate
term.description: Move backwards and forwards.

term.name: voltage
term.description: A way of saying how much energy is transferred by electricity.

term.name: voltmeter
term.description: An instrument for measuring voltage

term.name: volts (V)
term.description: Unit for voltage.

term.name: water resistance
term.description: A force that tries to slow things down that are moving through water. It is a type of friction.

term.name: water vapour
term.description: Water as a gas. Also called steam.

term.name: weight
term.description: The amount of force with which gravity pulls something towards the Earth. It is measured in newtons (N).

term.name: wind turbine
term.description: A kind of windmill that generates electricity using energy from the wind.

term.name: word equation
term.description: A way of writing out what happens in a chemical reaction.

term.name: xylem tissue
term.description: Found in roots, stems and leaves. Transports water.

term.name: year
term.description: The length of time it takes a planet to go around the Sun. One year on Earth is 365.25 days.
